docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of the Cytyc Corporation jumped 23 percent yesterday after the company said the United Healthcare Corporation, based in Minnetonka, Minn., had accepted Cytyc's Thinprep Pap test for coverage in health insurance plans. Shares of Cytyc rose $4.4375, to $23.4375. Analysts said the decision by United Healthcare, one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations, could mean that four million to six million of Cytyc's Pap tests would be used annually. The Thinprep test uses a thin film to analyze cervical cells and is an advance over the older Pap smear, United Healthcare said.

headline.main: CYTYC STOCK SOARS ON ACCEPTANCE OF ITS PAP TEST

docs.abstract: Shares of Cytyc Corp jump 23 percent after company says its Thinprep Pap test has been accepted by United Healthcare Corp for coverage in health insurance plans; United Healthcare claims Thinprep test is advance over older Pap smear (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: At a Rite Aid drugstore in Manhattan recently, a man handed the pharmacist a slip of paper he had torn from a pad hanging next to the condoms. After the pharmacy section cleared out, she gave him a bag with a home H.I.V. test inside. ''I wouldn't do it with all these people in there,'' said the pharmacist, Linda Lee. Many customers, she realizes, do not want to be seen taking kits off the counter, where they are displayed between nicotine patches and reading glasses.

headline.main: Sales of Home H.I.V. Tests Are Brisk, But Concern Persists Over Propriety

docs.abstract: HIV home tests are expected to grow into market worth $100 million to $200 million in five years, but questions remain about demographics of purchasers and propriety of giving possibly life-threatening test results over the phone; kits are manufactured by two companies, Home Access Health, and the Direct Access Diagnostics unit of Johnson & Johnson; they won Food and Drug Administration approval to market their kits last summer, after decade of being rebuffed; tests have 99.9 percent accuracy rate; manufacturers say slightly more than 1 percent of tests are registering positive for HIV; tests are costly, $35 to $50, but for many people, desire for secrecy outweighs price; challenge for manufacturers is who to aim their marketing at; tests are selling to gay men, teenagers, heterosexual adults, each likely to respond to different marketing; photos; charts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fay Vincent, whose initiatives when he was baseball commissioner included making the major leagues' health insurance plans available to players of the old Negro leagues, is now helping the needy in another way. He is making a personal gift of $2 million to Fairfield University in Connecticut to provide financial aid for students.

headline.main: Ex-Baseball Chief Gives to Fairfield U.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed into law yesterday a bill that bans health insurance companies from denying access to or setting higher rates for individuals who are genetically predisposed to certain diseases. The bill also prohibits employers from using or requiring genetic tests in the workplace. The Legislature approved the measure in June, but the Governor sought a technical revision. The measure was sent back to her last Thursday.
docs.abstract: New Jersey Governor Christine Todd Whitman signs into law bill that bans health insurance companies from denying access to or setting higher rates for individuals who are genetically predisposed to certain diseases; bill also prohibits employers from using or requiring genetic tests in workplace (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Upper West Side fish lovers who are also union supporters may choose to bypass Citarella, the popular market at 75th Street and Broadway for a few more months. On Friday, the National Labor Relations Board's regional director, Daniel Silverman, brought what he called the equivalent of a ''labor indictment'' against the store over the dismissal of three workers in August. ''We decided that there's enough evidence that the workers were fired for union activities to warrant a hearing before an administrative judge,'' Mr. Silverman said.
docs.abstract: NLRB issues 'labor indictment' of Citarella, fish shop on Manhattan's Upper West Side; finds evidence that three workers dismissed in August were fired for union activities; photo of pickets (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: REPORTS of child abuse and neglect are rising at an alarming rate all over the country. More than two million cases are now reported annually, about 30,000 in Connecticut alone. With about 65 percent of all cases involving injuries to the head and neck region, dental personnel are in a position to detect possible abuse of their patients. Dr. Lawrence Lipton, president of the Connecticut State Dental Association is also chairman of its Panda Coalition, an educational program designed to help dental office personnel recognize and report possible cases of abuse and neglect. Dr. Lipton, an assistant clinical professor at the University of Connecticut School of Dental Medicine, discussed in a recent interview the abuse problem and Panda's mission. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.

headline.main: Dentists on the Lookout for Child Abuse

docs.abstract: Dentist Dr Lawrence Lipton, in question and answer format, discusses organization Panda Coalition, which helps dental personnel recognize and report suspected child abuse; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was once a prestigious corporate address in downtown Newark. But in the last five years, as the operator's lease wound down, there was a marked decline in capital investment in the classic, 1930's office tower at 744 Broad Street, leading tenants to move out and more than doubling the building's vacancy rate to about 70 percent, brokers and the owner say. Because of this, the wedding cake-style, 543,548-square-foot structure -- at 35 stories one of the tallest in the state -- is now on the market. It is part of the city's ample supply of vacant secondary office space.

headline.main: As Old Offices Languish, the New in Newark Lease

docs.abstract: In the Region/New Jersey column discusses high vacant rates in once prestigious commercial buildings in Newark, NJ; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health maintenance organizations, which care for more than 60 million people, are telling courts across the country that they cannot be held responsible for medical malpractice in cases involving patients who receive care through employer-sponsored health plans. The H.M.O.'s argue that they are protected against malpractice claims and lawsuits by a 1974 Federal law that regulates employee benefits.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Using Federal Law to Deflect Malpractice Suits

docs.lead_paragraph: KIDS, cars and gifts get heavy play in the December crop of personal-finance magazines. Smart Money's special issue on children -- ''Your Biggest Investment'' -- is an exhaustive financial guide for parents. It covers about every conceivable aspect of the endeavor, from buying baby formula to paying for college to estate planning.

headline.main: Parenthood: The Eighth Financial Wonder of the World

docs.lead_paragraph: LOOKING to a future where far more people will require long-term care, the Government is beginning to encourage Americans to pay for it themselves. The carrot being offered is a tax deduction for individuals and employers on the purchase of long-term-care insurance. The stick is criminal penalties for some people who, instead of financing their own long-term care, try to become eligible for Government-paid care by shifting assets to family members or trusts. Officials and health care economists said the new incentives, which take effect on Jan. 1, herald sweeping changes in public policy. The Federal Government and states face daunting growth in entitlement programs like Medicaid that will soon be overrun by graying baby boomers and their parents.
docs.abstract: New Federal law offering tax deductions for purchase of long-term-care insurance, and penalties for asset-shifting to qualify for Medicaid, discusssed; Kennedy-Kassebaum bill may allow middle-class people to plan for such care themselves; employers will be able to deduct cost of providing long-term-care coverage, as with medical benefits; individuals may also take deductions, but consumer advocates advise close scrutiny of benefits and costs (S)
